workflow.name: Track SDK documentation drift with GitHub, Notion, Google Sheets, and Slack
workflow.description:
## üìä Description
Automatically track SDK releases from GitHub, compare documentation freshness in Notion, and send Slack alerts when docs lag behind. This workflow ensures documentation stays in sync with releases, improves visibility, and reduces version drift across teams. üöÄüìöüí¨

## What This Template Does
- Step 1: Listens to GitHub repository events to detect new SDK releases. üß©
- Step 2: Fetches release metadata including version, tag, and publish date. üì¶
- Step 3: Logs release data into Google Sheets for record-keeping and analysis. üìä
- Step 4: Retrieves FAQ or documentation data from Notion. üìö
- Step 5: Merges GitHub and Notion data to calculate documentation drift. üîç
- Step 6: Flags SDKs whose documentation is over 30 days out of date. ‚ö†Ô∏è
- Step 7: Sends detailed Slack alerts to notify responsible teams. üîî

## Key Benefits
‚úÖ Keeps SDK documentation aligned with product releases
 ‚úÖ Prevents outdated information from reaching users
 ‚úÖ Provides centralized release tracking in Google Sheets
 ‚úÖ Sends real-time Slack alerts for overdue updates
 ‚úÖ Strengthens DevRel and developer experience operations

## Features
- GitHub release trigger for real-time monitoring
- Google Sheets logging for tracking and auditing
- Notion database integration for documentation comparison
- Automated drift calculation (days since last update)
- Slack notifications for overdue documentation

## Requirements
- GitHub OAuth2 credentials
- Notion API credentials
- Google Sheets OAuth2 credentials
- Slack Bot token with chat:write permissions
- Target Audience
- Developer Relations (DevRel) and SDK engineering teams
- Product documentation and technical writing teams
- Project managers tracking SDK and doc release parity

## Step-by-Step Setup Instructions
- Connect your GitHub account and select your SDK repository.
- Replace YOUR_GOOGLE_SHEET_ID and YOUR_SHEET_GID with your tracking spreadsheet.
- Add your Notion FAQ database ID.
- Configure your Slack channel ID for alerts.
- Run once manually to validate setup, then enable automation.

workflow.name: Automate SDK Version Drift Detection with GitHub, Notion, and Slack

parameters.content:
## üéØ SDK Release Tracker Workflow

### Purpose
Automatically tracks SDK releases from GitHub and monitors if documentation (FAQs) in Notion are kept up-to-date. Sends Slack alerts when documentation is >30 days behind.

### Flow Overview
1. **Trigger**: GitHub repository event
2. **Fetch**: Get all releases from repository
3. **Transform**: Extract release metadata
4. **Log**: Save to Google Sheets
5. **Compare**: Match with Notion FAQ updates
6. **Calculate**: Compute drift (days since last update)
7. **Alert**: Send Slack notification if overdue

### Requirements
- GitHub OAuth2 credentials
- Google Sheets OAuth2 credentials
- Notion API credentials
- Slack API credentials

### Setup Note
Replace the following with your own:
- Google Sheet ID (2 locations)
- Notion Database ID
- Slack Channel ID

## üìå GitHub Trigger Setup

### Configuration
- **Event**: Repository events
- **Monitors**: Any changes to the repository
- **Triggers on**: Releases, tags, and repository updates

### Setup Steps
1. Connect your GitHub OAuth2 account
2. Select target repository
3. Choose "repository" event type

‚ö†Ô∏è **Replace** repository with your own SDK repository

## üì• Fetch All Releases

### What It Does
Retrieves all published releases from the GitHub repository to process latest version information.

### Configuration
- **Resource**: Release
- **Operation**: Get All
- **Return All**: Yes (fetches complete release history)

### Output
Release data including tag, name, date, and URL

## üîÑ Transform Release Data

### Purpose
Structures raw GitHub release data into a clean format for logging and analysis.

### Fields Extracted
- SDK Name (from repository)
- Release Tag (version number)
- Release Title
- Release Date (ISO format)
- Release URL
- Days Since Release (calculated)

## üìä Log to Google Sheets

### Purpose
Creates a persistent record of all SDK releases for tracking and reporting.

### Configuration
- **Operation**: Append (adds new rows)
- **Mapping**: Auto-map input data

‚ö†Ô∏è **Replace** Sheet ID with your own tracking spreadsheet

## üìö Fetch FAQ Data

### Purpose
Retrieves all FAQ/documentation pages from Notion to compare update dates with releases.

### Configuration
- **Resource**: Database Page
- **Operation**: Get All
- **Return All**: Yes

‚ö†Ô∏è **Replace** Database ID with your Notion FAQ database

## üîÄ Merge Data Streams

### Purpose
Combines release data (from Sheets) with FAQ data (from Notion) for drift calculation.


### Output
Combined dataset ready for drift analysis

## üßÆ Calculate Documentation Drift

### Purpose
Computes how many days documentation lags behind SDK releases.

### Logic
1. For each SDK release:
   - Get release date
   - Find corresponding FAQ update date
   - Calculate days between them

## üíæ Update Drift Status

### Purpose
Writes calculated drift metrics back to Google Sheets for reporting.

### Operation
Appends drift analysis results as new rows

## üö¶ Filter Overdue Items

### Purpose
Identifies SDKs with documentation >30 days behind for alerting.

### Condition
Overdue Status = "OVERDUE"

## üîî Slack Alert

### Purpose
Notifies team about overdue documentation via Slack.

### Message Format
üö® SDK Version Drift Alert

**SDK Name** ‚Üí X days since FAQ update
Latest Release: YYYY-MM-DD

user.name: Rahul Joshi
user.bio: Rahul Joshi is a seasoned technology leader specializing in the n8n automation tool and AI-driven workflow automation. With deep expertise in building open-source workflow automation and self-hosted automation platforms, he helps organizations eliminate manual processes through intelligent n8n ai agent automation solutions.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
